A B S T R A C T
Converting carbon dioxide (CO2) into value-added chemicals by CO2 reduction has been considered as a potential way to solve the current energy crisis and environmental problem. Among the methods of CO2 reduction, the electrochemical method has been widely used due to its mild reaction condition and high reaction efficiency. In the electrochemical reduction system, the CO2 electrocatalyst is the most important part. Although many CO2 electrocatalysts have been developed, efficient catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability are still lacking. Copper sulfide compound, as a low-toxicity and emerging material, has broad prospects in the field of CO2 reduction due to its unique structural and electrochemical properties. Much progress has been achieved with copper sulfide nanocrystalline and the field is rapidly developing. This paper summarizes the preparation, recent progress in development, and factors affecting the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance with copper sulfide compound as a catalyst. Prospects for future development are also outlined, with the aim of using copper sulfide compound as a highly active and stable electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the industrial revolution, fossil fuels such as coal, oil and natural gas have been massively mined and utilized. As non-renewable energy resources, fossil fuels have two fatal flaws. First, the limited reserves cannot meet the growing energy demand, leading to a serious energy crisis. Second, the use of fossil fuels for energy production emits a large amount of CO2 into the atmosphere, causing global environmental problems [1,2], such as global warming, sea level rise, land desertification, etc. For sustainable development, it is extremely urgent to reduce the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. Scientists have made many efforts to achieve this goal. Starting from the source, clean and CO2–free renewable energy has been developed to replace the use of fossil fuels for energy production [3–14]. Converting CO2 into value added carbon fuels, including CO, HCOOH/HCOO , CH2O, CH4, CH3OH, H2C2O4/HC2O4 , C2H4, CH3CH2OH and other products through chemical

methods has been utilized to recycle the CO2 [15–20]. Normally, the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can be achieved by photochemical reduction [21–24], electrochemical reduction [25–27], biochemical reduction [28–30] and so on. Electrocatalytic CO2RR has attracted much attention because of its virtues of process controllability, mild reaction environment and high reaction efficiency [31–34]. In addition, renewable energies such as solar energy and wind energy can be used as power sources to conduct electrocatalytic CO2RR, enabling storage and redistribution of the renewable energy, as shown in Fig. 1 [35–37]. Therefore, electro-catalytic CO2RR has become an important research field with a wide application prospect.
Although much progress has been made, some problems still exist with the practical application of electrocatalytic CO2RR, including [32, 33] (1) high reduction potential for CO2 electrochemical conversion; (2) slow kinetics of CO2 electroreduction; (3) low energy conversion efficiency; (4) poor catalytic selectivity; (5) insufficient stability; and (6)

competitive hydrogen evolution reaction. The key to solving these problems is to develop high performance electrocatalysts with good activity, selectivity, and stability.
The electrocatalysts for CO2RR can be classified into two categories: metal catalysts and non-metal catalysts. The non-metal catalysts are mainly carbon-based materials [38–40]. The metal catalysts include metal elements and their associated compounds such as metals, metal alloys, metal oxides and metal complexes [15,32,41–48]. Different metal catalysts result in differences in the activity and selectivity of the CO2RR because of the differences in the adsorption strength of the intermediates. According to the selectivity for final products, the metal catalysts can be further classified into four categories [49–52]: (1) Cd, Hg, Sn, In, Bi, Pb, Pd, etc., which easily produce HCOO intermediate, and form formate as the main product; (2) Au, Ag, Zn, etc., because of the weak CO adsorption capacity, resulting in CO as main reduction product; (3) Ni, Fe, Si, V, Pt, etc., mainly to produce H2 due to the low hydrogen evolution potential; (4) Cu, under different conditions, can produce 16 different carbon-containing compounds, including various multi–carbon products.
Studies have shown that Cu is the only catalyst that can reduce CO2 to high energy density multi–carbon products and thus has attracted much attention. However, the key step in the C–C bond formation needed for the multi–carbon products induces an extra barrier in the reaction, which causes low activity and poor selectivity. To solve this problem, scientists have conducted much research on ways to improve catalyst performance, the mechanism of electrocatalytic CO2RR, and in other directions. It has been found that the activity and selectivity of Cu catalysts in the reaction process are affected by multiple factors. Hori et al. [53,54] found that different crystal surfaces of Cu could yield different reduction products. He found that the main product of the Cu (111) surface is methane, and the Cu (100) surface is selective for C2 products like ethylene and ethanol. Rcskc et al. [55] found that the catalytic activity and product selectivity of nanoscale Cu particles were much higher than that of bulk metal Cu. Chen et al. [56] investigated the performance of the single atom Cu catalyst, and found it has better performance than other investigated materials. The catalyst morphology also plays an important role. Chorkendorff et al. [57] discovered that Cu electrodes with different surface roughness have different product selectivity for CO2RR. They reported a Cu nanoparticle coated electrode has better selectivity for hydrocarbons than other uncoated electrodes. Also, different morphologies of Cu–based catalysts have been synthesized and studied for electrocatalytic CO2RR such as nanowires [58,59], films [60], microcubes [61], core–shell [62–64], etc. The research results showed that the catalytic performance can be remarkably improved through changing the catalysts’ structure and morphology.
In recent years, more and more research has been reported on Cu metal compounds. By introducing other elements into Cu metal electrodes, the resultant different bonding modes with Cu and multiple binding sites for intermediate species will have a great influence on the performance of the catalyst [15,18,65–73]. Sulfur belongs to theⅥ group element and the sulfur compound has excellent optical and electrical
properties [74–77]. The bonding form of the S atom is various. For example, S has small electronegativity, easily reacts with the metal element to form an ionic compound, and has the capacity to bond with itself to form a chain-shaped polysulfide ion Sn2 . Due to the various bonding modes of S atoms, the structure of sulfides tends to be diversified and complicated, which means that S is an attractive candidate as a modifier for electrocatalysts. Copper sulfide compounds with different S content, combination and element composition have various phase states, morphologies and crystal structures. It has been widely used in catalysis [19], optoelectronic equipment [78,79], photovoltaic panels [80–82], sensors [83], biomedicine [84,85] and other fields. In the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR, the S atom can effectively suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and significantly influence the absorption and desorption strength of CO2 reduction intermediates [86,87]. For that reason, copper sulfide compounds have promising prospects for improving catalytic activity and product selectivity.
At present, there is much research about copper sulfide compound electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Most showed good selectivity and high activity. This paper reviews the recent progress in the utilization of copper sulfide compounds in the field of electrochemical CO2RR. We first introduce several methods for preparing different nanostructures of copper sulfide compounds. Then, we summarize recent reports on the utilization of copper sulfide compounds as electrocatalysts to reduce CO2. We analyze the morphology, size, composition, substrate and other factors which affect the catalytic performance and the reaction mechanism in the electrochemical CO2RR process. Finally, we list the existing problems and make proposals for future research and development.
2. Preparation methods of copper sulfide compound
Binary copper sulfide compound, also known as Cu2-xS, is a direct band gap semiconductor nano-material with excellent absorption of visible light, which has a variety of stoichiometric compositions, multiple nanocrystal morphologies, complex crystal structures and valence states [88–91]. Research shows that several phases of Cu2-xS nanocrystal exist, with the value of x from 0 to 1, such as Cu2S (chalcocite), Cu1⋅97S (djurleite), Cu1⋅80S (digenite), Cu1⋅40S (spionkopite), CuS (covelline), etc. [92,93]. Cu2-xS is a typical p-type semiconductor material, which has a large number of Cu holes in the crystal lattice. The bond length of the Cu–Cu bond and the Cu–S bond in Cu2-xS is close to the bond length of the Cu–Cu bond in the metal Cu, and thus exhibits excellent conductivity [94,95]. In particular, CuS has a peculiar crystal structure in which one-third of the copper atoms are coordinated with three sulfur atoms, and the remaining two-thirds of the copper atoms are surrounded by four sulfur atoms to form a tetrahedral structure which exhibits a special superconducting property at 1.63 K [96].
Ternary copper sulfide compound is formed by introducing other metal elements (such as Na, In, Ag, K, etc.) on the basis of Cu2-xS. The Cu atom in the ternary copper sulfide compound generally exists in the form of þ1 valence or in a mixed valence state. The various coordination

67 68 69 70 71 72 73 74 75 76 modes make the material have various crystal structures such as a onedimensional chain structure, layer structure, octahedral structure, etc. With the introduction of different elements, the physicochemical properties are different, so it has a very broad application prospect. The synthesis of copper sulfide compounds has been studied for decades. By controlling the reaction temperature, time and environment, copper sulfide nanocrystals with different morphologies and structures can be obtained. The special surface topography endows the material with new and outstanding characteristics, leading to broader application prospects in several fields.

sections.heading: 2.1. Solvothermal method
sections.text:
The solvothermal method, also known as the hydrothermal method, uses solvent as the reaction medium and high temperature and a pressure resistant container as the reactor. After high temperature and pressure through external heating, the insoluble matter at normal temperature and pressure will be dissolved and recrystallized to form the target product. The products synthesized by the solvothermal method have the characteristics of high dispersion, small size, uniformity, controllable morphology and low cost.
Zheng et al. [97] reported that high dispersion CuS microspheres were synthesized by the solvothermal method, as shown in Fig. 2. Using [Bmim]2Cu2Cl6 as the precursor and thiourea (TU) as the sulfur source, a series of CuS microspheres with diameters of 2.5–4 μm assembled by nanosheets with thicknesses of 10–15 nm were obtained. Hu et al. [98] synthesized special flower-like CuS nanocrystals using chloride (CuCl2⋅2H2O) as the precursor, TU as the sulfur source and ethylene glycol (C2H6O2) as the solvent. Well-defined products were obtained with good control over size and shape by template and other reaction conditions.
Saranya et al. [99] found that the final product's morphology directly correlated with the sulfur source under the same reaction condition. For example, they prepared self-assembled CuS nanostructures with TU as the sulfur source and different CuS nanostructures with thioacetamide (TAA) as the sulfur source under the same reaction temperature and time.

sections.heading: 2.2. Hot injection method
sections.text:
Hot injection is a method for synthesizing nanocrystals in the liquid phase. The key in this method is to rapidly inject a lower temperature precursor solution into a higher temperature organic solvent, resulting in the rapid formation of a large number of crystal nucleuses. After the temperature is reduced, the crystal nucleus grows in a predetermined direction to form nanocrystals with different morphologies under the
Fig. 2. Schematic illustration of the preparati
guidance of the surfactant. The reaction process is shown in Fig. 3. The hot injection method separates the nucleation and growth process into two different stages by controlling the reaction temperature, avoiding secondary nucleation and ensuring monodisperse and high-quality nanocrystals.
Li et al. [101] adopted the hot injection method to prepare high-quality CuS nanocrystals in an oleic acid/liquid paraffin system using copper oxide (CuO) and elemental S as the precursors without inert gas. At first, they mixed CuO, oleic acid and liquid paraffin as precursor A, and then they mixed elemental S and liquid paraffin as precursor B. Then, precursor A and precursor B were stirred and heated to 180 C and 120 C, respectively, until homogeneous solutions were obtained. Finally, precursor B was swiftly injected into precursor A, and CuS nanoparticles were obtained.
By controlling the reaction temperature, Olesiak et al. [102] synthesized Cu2S nanorods and accomplished effective regulation of the nanorods’ length. Tao et al. [103] introduced halogen ions (Cl , Br , I ) to regulate the growth of the crystal surface to synthesize special triangular nano-prism CuS by the hot injection method.

sections.heading: 2.3. Template method
sections.text:
The template method is divided into the soft template method and the hard template method. The soft template is formed by the aggregation of surfactant molecules, and the hard template is a rigid template maintained by covalent bond. The template method can effectively regulate the size, morphology, structure, arrangement and other factors of nanomaterials through its structure orientation or spatial limiting action. Due to its highly adjustable morphology and structure, this method is widely used by researchers to prepare nanomaterials with special structures such as nanotubes, nanowires and hollow spheres.
Wu et al. [104] used Cu2O nanospheres as templates to prepare CuS hollow nanospheres through carrying out a sulfurization reaction at 40 C. The formation mechanism of a hollow sphere is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 4a. At first, S2 released by STS reacted with Cu2O on the surface of the sphere to produce CuS, forming the core-shell structure covered with CuS on the surface of the Cu2O. Because the diffusion velocity of Cu2þ is faster than that of S2 in the CuS shell, the production of CuS on the outside of the shell is faster than that on the inside of the shell. As a result, the Cu2O/CuS core-shell structures completely transform to CuS hollow nanospheres (Fig. 4b). Similarly, Sun et al. [105] reported a one-step synthesis of unique polyhedral 26-facet CuS microcages (Fig. 4c), using polyhedral 26-facet Cu2O as templates.

Using electrochemical deposition, Xu et al. [106] obtained different sizes of Cu2S and CuS nanowires (Fig. 5a) by adjusting the reaction voltage and temperature. The obtained nanowires had a diameter of up to 300 μm. The two-electrode deposition system is assembled as shown in Fig. 5b. Under the copper redox potential window, CuS nanocrystals were obtained on the surface of the electrode.
In addition to the preparation of nanowires, electrochemical deposition can also be used to prepare specific size CuS nanoclusters or to deposit CuS films on the surface of other materials to form heterogeneous composite structures.

sections.heading: 2.5. Chemical vapor deposition
sections.text:
Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is a technique to obtain desired solid film products or coatings by heating, plasma excitation and optical radiation. The reaction process can be roughly divided into three steps: (1) use gas as reaction material or vaporize solid as volatile material; (2) transfer the above mentioned materials to the deposition area; (3) chemical reactions occur on solid substrates to form solid products. CVD has a wide range of applications, and can be used to purify substances, develop new crystals, and deposit various kinds of single crystal, polycrystal and glassy inorganic thin film materials.
As shown in Fig. 6a, the utilization of different components between Cu and S will synthesize different Cu2-xS with different phases, properties and crystal structures [107]. Bang et al. [108] obtained Cu2-xS with varying compositions and different morphologies by precisely controlling the components of Cu and S (Fig. 4b–4e).
3. Applying copper sulfide compounds to electrochemical CO2RR
Electrochemical reduction of CO2 belongs to the typical heterogeneous catalytic reaction. The heterogeneous catalytic reaction process can be summarized into three steps, which are: (1) gaseous or liquid reactants adsorbed on the surface of the solid catalyst; (2) reactants like CO2 turn into different intermediate products through the gain or loss of electrons, and reduce to the final reduction products; and (3) desorption of the final reduction products. In the CO2 reduction process, the catalyst's type, size, structure, even different substrates have a great influence on the above three-step reaction process. In the past, copper sulfide compound was commonly used in other catalytic fields such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER), HER, photocatalytic reaction, etc. [19,72,99, 109–117]. In recent years, copper sulfide compound has been continuously selected as a catalyst for electrochemical reduction, especially for CO2 reduction.

sections.heading: 3.1. Factors influencing activity and selectivity
sections.text: From recent reports about copper sulfide catalysts on CO2RR, it can be found that several factors could efficiently affect the catalytic performance, such as morphology, component, size, and so on.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Morphology and structure
sections.text:
Regulating the morphology and structure of the catalyst has always
been one of the hot strategies to optimize the catalytic performance, and has achieved many excellent research results. By regulating the morphology and structure, the physicochemical properties of the promoter can be changed, thereby changing the catalytic activity and selectivity. For example, it can effectively improve the active area of the catalyst [118,119], increase active sites for specific needs [120]#, generate novel and interesting physical phenomena [25,121], change the adsorption strength of the catalyst on the electrolyte or CO2 [19,122], etc.
For the copper sulfide compound, the catalyst morphology and structure affecting the performance have been the focus in the
electrochemical CO2RR field. Zhu et al. [123] reported the first work on the electrochemical reduction of CO2 using a Cu2S catalyst in an H-cell, as shown in Fig. 7a. After anodization and heat treatment of a copper foam electrode, a Cu2S nanoarray (Fig. 7b) was obtained on the copper foam by electro-deposition in a Na2S aqueous solution. The nanoarray had a nanosheet morphology and a thickness which could be easily controlled by varying the deposition potential and time. The obtained Cu2S/Cu electrode was very efficient in reducing CO2 to HCOOH. The faradaic efficiency (FE) of formic acid production and the reduction current density could reach 85% and 5.3mA/cm2, respectively, at the potential of 2.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl . The selectivity of the Cu2S/Cu electrode to formic acid is much higher than that of the pure Cu electrode without S-doped modification (Fig. 7c). This high selectivity toward formate can be attributed to the surface morphologies with more Cu2S-derived Cu0 catalyst. By changing the morphology and structure, the selectivity to the final
product can be shifted to other single-carbon products. Shao et al. [124] reported a research on the synthesis of hollow CuS (h-CuS) microcubes (Fig. 8a) through the galvanic replacement reaction of the Cu2O microcubes (Fig. 8b) precursor, and used it as an electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction. The h-CuS microcubes exposed more edge sites due to their

One was the special morphology of the nanoarray, which had more exposed active sites and a faster ion and electro transfer rate. In the control experiments, the catalytic activity of the CuS nanowire sample was much lower than that of the nanosheet samples, as shown in Fig. 9d and Fig. 9e. The other was that the presence of S atoms could stabilize the adsorption of the CO2* intermediate, thereby increasing the selectivity of the CH4. In summary, the morphology of the copper sulfide compound has great influence on the activity and selectivity of electrochemical CO2RR. As mentioned above, through different synthetic methods, a variety of different copper sulfide materials with strange morphology can be obtained, such as hollow spheres, flower-like nanocrystals, 26-facet microcages, etc. These special morphologically structured copper sulfide compounds have not been reported for electrochemical CO2RR before, and further research in this field should be conducted in the future.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Component and particle size
sections.text:
With different S content, copper sulfide catalysts have different
structures and properties. In order to study the influence of the S content in the catalytic process, Huang et al. [125] designed an S–doped Cu2O–derived Cu catalyst. As shown in Fig. 10a, Cu2O was immersed in an ammonium polysulfide solution, and Cu2-xS catalysts with different S content were obtained by controlling the concentration of ammonium polysulfide (0–5000 μM). The content of sulfur caused the morphology change of the copper sulfide catalyst (Fig. 10b). They found that the ability to reduce CO2 to formate was proportional to the S content of the catalysts (Fig. 10c and d). The catalyst with the highest S content of 2.7 atom% showed the largest FE of 75% at 0.8 V vs. RHE and the largest formate current density of 13.9mA/cm2 at 0.9 V vs. RHE. However, this work just simply confirmed the relationship between S content and product selectivity. The special phase states with different composition, like Cu1⋅97S, Cu1⋅80S, and others have not been further synthesized and studied in the CO2RR field.

In addition to the S content, the catalyst's size also affects the electrocatalytic performance. Shinagawa et al. [126] found that the initial particle size of the copper sulfide catalyst positively affected the selectivity of formate from CO2RR. The carbon-supported copper sulfide catalysts were prepared by wet chemistry under He atmosphere. Using TU as the sulfide precursor and simultaneously controlling the concentration of Cu and S precursors in the solution, granular CuS with different particle size (CuS–1 to CuS–4) could be obtained. The experiment proved that the selectivity of the formate product is proportional to the particle size of the CuS catalyst, meaning larger particle size corresponds to higher FEs to formate (Fig. 11).

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Substrate
sections.text:
Combined with different substrates, the interface also affects the electronic structure of the copper sulfide compound. Kahsay et al. [127] used the successive ionic layer adsorption reaction (SILAR) method to deposit CuS onto a thermally prepared Cu2O/CuO/Cu heterostructure (Fig. 12). This CuS/Cu2O/CuO/Cu heterostructure electrocatalyst reached a high FE of 84% for formate production at the potential of 0.7 V vs. RHE with a current density of 20mA/cm2. It was much higher than that of the unsupported CuS electrocatalyst. Yuan et al. [128] fabricated CuInS2 and CuInS2/graphene hybrid thin films in dimethyl sulfoxide by simple one-step electrodeposition at 30 C. By comparing the CO2 electrochemical reduction result of CuInS2 and CuInS2/graphene as electrocatalysts, they found that the current densities under illumination of CuInS2/graphene catalysts were almost twice those of CuInS2 thin films, and the rate of methanol formation at
CuInS2/graphene was about 1.4 times that at CuInS2. The experiment results showed that the graphene substrate had a great influence on the catalytic performance, both in activity and selectivity.

sections.text:

reduction product such as introducing other elements, importing optical

fields, changing cocatalysts. Yuan et al. [129] did a series of studies on the electrochemical reduction of CO2 by CuInS2 catalyst. They fabricated a p-CuInS2 thin film by electrodepositing a Cu–In alloy layer and then sulfuring. The prepared-CuInS2 thin film was used as the photoelectrode in the solar-driven photoelectrochemical reduction of CO2 to methanol, and it could occur at 0.54 V vs. the saturated calomel electrode (SCE), with a faradaic efficiency of 97% and stabilization time of 11 h. As the obtained CuInS2 thin film was a p-type semiconductor, the current density in magnitude was larger under illumination than in the dark. The experiment results showed that the combining with the extra element indium and the introduction of an optical field had significant effects on the catalytic performance. In this electrochemical system, they also studied the coverage of pyridine at the CuInS2 thin film photoelectrode [130] and found that the mass transfer resistance resulting from the pyridine adsorption layer slowed down the reduction rate of CO2.
Copper sulfide compounds have unique photoelectrochemical properties. In the field of electrochemical CO2 reduction, there has been some basic research. The research on the selective reduction of formate is relatively mature, and can obtain higher FE at lower potential. In addition, methane, methanol and other products can be selectively controlled by controlling the morphology, introducing other elements or external field. The application of copper sulfide compounds in the field of CO2 reduction has great research potential, and it is worthwhile to continue to explore.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR
sections.text:
On the basis of the above research, scientists have further studied the mechanism in the electrochemical CO2RR by copper sulfide catalysts. Through in situ surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (Fig. 13a), Phillips et al. [131] found that HCOO* intermediates were not formed during the reduction process, which means that formate was formed by the one-step reaction of physically adsorbed CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 13b). A strong adsorption peak of CO was found in the infrared spectrum, while no CO was found in the reduction products, indicating that CO was tightly bound to the catalyst's surface. Combined with the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, they proposed that this selectivity was due to the stronger binding of the CO intermediate originating from the remaining subsurface S atoms. The adsorbed CO intermediate could be further selectively reduced to formate at other sites.
Through the first principle of simulating the process for CuS electrochemical CO2 reduction, García-Muelas et al. [87] explained why sulfur-modified copper catalysts have a strong selectivity to formate. The simulation result can be summarized into three points: (1) the presence of basic sites where CO2 is tethered blocking its dissociation toward CO, (2) the ability of chalcogens to transfer hydrides to CO2, and (3) the effective blocking of unselective paths on the surrounding Cu atoms.
Almost at the same time, based on previous studies on S content and formate selectivity, Yeo et al. [86] continued to delve into the role of S in
the enhanced formation of formate on SD-Cu [131].

the selective electrochemical reduction of formate on CuS catalysts. By comparing CO2 catalytic performance with active CuSx, desulfurized CuSx and bare Cu catalysts, they found that the high selectivity toward formate production can be attributed to the effect of S-doped into the Cu catalyst, rather than the surface morphology. By combining DFT calculation s and isotopic labeling operando Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 14), the results showed that the presence of sulfur weakens the *COOH and HCOO* adsorption energies, which suppress the formation of *COOH toward CO and reduce the energy of the potential-limiting step for formate production. Both hence enhance the formation of formate.
We can conclude that, for the copper sulfide catalyst, S is the main promoter of the catalytic performance. The doping of the S atom offers different electrochemical properties, increases the electroactive surface area of the material and improves the ion and electron transport rate. From recent research, the S atom has the ability to combine the hydride with the physical CO2 adsorption capability to form formate, and change the adsorption strength of the CO2 reduction reaction intermediate to reduce the energy barrier.

sections.heading: 4. Problems and future prospects
sections.text:
The research on copper sulfide compounds in the electrochemical CO2RR field has just begun, and there are still many problems that have not been solved. For example, in electrochemical CO2RR, many factors can affect the activity and selectivity of the final products, such as morphology, structure, S ion, Cu vacancy and others, but which of these factors play a crucial role is still not clear. CuS is not stable in the reduction process and can easily convert into CuO or Cu2O. Thus, exactly which material is working in the CO2 reduction process also needs to be figured out. Furthermore, currently, little research has been developed that can reduce CO2 to high energy density multi–carbon products by means of copper sulfide catalyst. These questions are not only obstacles to large-scale application, but also point the direction for further research to find better copper sulfide catalysts.
Based on current developments and existing problems, it is recommended that further research be carried out from the following five aspects.
First, new synthesis strategies are needed to prepare copper sulfide materials with different special morphologies and crystal structures such as nano-tips, nanoparticles, two dimensional layered structures, etc., to improve the performance of the catalyst.
Second, preparation of copper sulfide crystals with different phase states such as Cu1⋅97S, Cu1⋅80S, etc., is needed to explore whether the copper sulfide materials with atypical crystal structure have different performance during electrochemical CO2RR.
Third, methods for reducing CO2 to high value multi-carbon products by copper sulfide compound catalysts need to be researched. For example, refer to Xiao's research that studied the C–C coupling by CuO
Fig. 14. Raman spectra of bare Cu and AC–CuSx (before being used as catalysts) [86].
115 116 117 118 119 120 121 122 123 124 125 126 127 128 129 130 131 132
and Cuþ series reaction [132], to make S or Cu vacancies or to introduce other elements to reduce CO2 to multi-carbon products.
Fourth, research is needed on the reaction mechanism, such as by exploring the influence of surface adsorbate (like hydroxyl) on the catalytic performance during the reaction, and obtaining the changes of material surface in the catalytic process through in situ characterization to clarify the catalytic active sites.
Fifth, other variables such as light, heat, etc., need to be introduced to synergistically bias the electric field to improve the performance of the catalyst; or the synthesis of other polynary copper sulfide compounds for electrochemical CO2RR.
Sixth, the method of stabilizing CuS in the catalytic process without converting it to CuO needs to be explored. It is also possible to explore the method of stabilizing S vacancies from another perspective.

sections.heading: 5. Summary
sections.text: QIn recent years, CO2 reduction has attracted more and more attention due to its broad development prospects. Scientists conduct much research from all directions, hoping to obtain catalysts with low cost, high activity, high selectivity and high stability. Copper sulfide compounds, which have been widely used in OER, HER, degrade and other electrocatalytic fields, have attracted attention due to their unique and excellent electrochemical properties. In this paper, the conventional preparation methods of copper sulfide nanomaterials and their research on electrochemical CO2RR were reviewed, and the factors and reasons affecting the CO2RR performance were summarized. Based on this, the paper puts forward the idea of the need for further research and points out the great development prospect of copper sulfide compounds in the field of electrochemical CO2RR.

metadata.abstractText: Converting carbon dioxide (CO2) into value-added chemicals by CO2 reduction has been considered as a potential way to solve the current energy crisis and environmental problem. Among the methods of CO2 reduction, the electrochemical method has been widely used due to its mild reaction condition and high reaction efficiency. In the electrochemical reduction system, the CO2 electrocatalyst is the most important part. Although many CO2 electrocatalysts have been developed, efficient catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability are still lacking. Copper sulfide compound, as a low-toxicity and emerging material, has broad prospects in the field of CO2 reduction due to its unique structural and electrochemical properties. Much progress has been achieved with copper sulfide nanocrystalline and the field is rapidly developing. This paper summarizes the preparation, recent progress in development, and factors affecting the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance with copper sulfide compound as a catalyst. Prospects for future development are also outlined, with the aim of using copper sulfide compound as a highly active and stable electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction. 92
